ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Components of writing a personal essay, writing about different ranges of topics, experimenting with style.
How to write a personal essay a lot better
Writing personal essays on various topics, such as places, things, and books.

My writing skills grew tremendously over the course of the semester. I got much less wordy and better at exploringrather than arguinga point in my writing. I had so much fun being creative and exploring that side of myself.
I learned how to use models to enhance and develop my writing, how to read essays for craft, and how to revise
everything - communicating my ideas, writing, reading, working in a group

I learned about the versatility and strength of writing in a personal essay format. Through writing four personal essays, I've started to build an "I" character, a way of writing about myself I'm certain I'll use in future writing. I practiced introspecting on past experiences and current thoughts, writing them out, and editing them into an essay. I also gained insights into the experiences of a slice of my classmates at Yale through the essays they shared in workshopshonest and revealing stories about similar and different backgrounds, views, and lives.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: Engaging readings, none of the assignments every felt like busy work. Lots of opportunities to workshop your essays/ Weaknesses: none! This is a great course to improve your skills as a writer.
Professor is amazing

Professor Sharlin was very encouraging with the class discussions, this was helpful. Weaknesses for this course were unavoidable due to remote teaching  a fair amount of the spontaneity of in-person seminar discussions was lost.

Professor Sharlin picked out fantastic essays for us to read. They were engaging, and I always looked forward to reading them. She also did a great job facilitating discussions, especially when we workshopped each other's essays.

Although changing the meeting style kept things interesting, it would have been nice to have a consistent group of people to work and talk with through the semester. I often felt like we were changing groups right as I was getting comfortable with the peers I was working with.

only strenghts, no weaknesses - this was the best english class I have ever taken; the class size is perfect, the workshops are amazing, super engaging, and meeting with the teacher one-on-one to discuss the essay is amazing, have access to tutors too is super super helpful!

The readings, carefully curated, spanned several styles of the personal essay and were from all kinds of authors. I loved picking up new readings not knowing what to expect, and I also was amazed at how free all of us were to voice our likes and dislikes of particular pieces. Learning what made writing good included learning what made a personal piece, and the author as a result, unlikeable. Peer review was also so helpful. Professor Sharlin's feedback, sent in a word document with comments highlighting details and also useful general comments, was useful, but so was feedback from peersand Professor Sharlin understood this. I found myself very seriously addressing every comment made by my peers after a workshop or small group session. I'm pretty satisfied with how we were able to trust and respect each other while we discussed one another's work and stories, and I wish we could have gotten to know each other just a little more.

We always had interesting discussions about readings of essays from notable writers. Still, it was sometimes hard to take tangible lessons from our observations about their essays. Even if we did, it was difficult to directly apply some of the creative sentence structures. Perhaps this is just another level of writing that requires more editing sessions, time, and experience.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The discussion in this class went very smoothly, not too different from an in-person experience.
Shifra was so wonderfully accommodating during such a difficult semester. She lightened our workload and worked with our feedback in mind. I feel so grateful.
My only real complaint is that this course couldn't be in-person!

everything succeeded - the seminar form was perfect, breakout rooms helped us to separate into smaller groups; ater vaccination, we also managed to meet in very small groups outside, which was amazing

I felt very grateful when Professor Sharlin sent a revised schedule/syllabus about halfway through the semester to reduce our reading and essay workload. In addition, she removed some full-class meetings and replaced a portion of them with small group sessions. Smaller groups allowed for more discussion per person, and after first draft revisions, discussion on each person's piece even if you weren't workshopped by the whole class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! English 120 is a great way to get out of the world of rigid academic writing; this class lets you read and write personal essays that are far more meaningful to you.
Yes! English 120 is a great course no matter what skill level you come in with. There are writing partners, peer workshops, and instructor feedback to help you improve.
Yes was amazing and enlightening
Yes. I learned so much about myself from writing these essays. And my writing improved a lot.
Yes, great introduction to writing the personal essay, something I was not previously familiar with.
Yes! This is such a fantastic course for anyone just interested in writing. It was fun to read essayists' works and try to apply their techniques in my own writing.

DEFINITELY! this class is insane. prof. sharlin was the best, but i bet most engl 120 profs are. this class is just sooo much fun. it is a lot of writing, but if you like creative writing and want to have freedom, explore differnt stiles, and recieve amazing feedback, it doesn't feel like work. i nthe end, we only had to revise one more essay, but I rewrtoe two, just because this class made writing so much fun. it made it feel natural, real, and just a distraction. the topics are so broad, but they also give you direction, which allows you to wrtie about exactly what you want. everyone says that engl 120 is iconic and they are right. there is nothing more i can say, except that I am a stem major and this is my favourite class.

I strongly recommend this course! This is a meaningful WR credit where you feel freedom to explore your personal experiences and try new things in your writing. The workload was not so much heavy, as it was uncertain on an individual basisbrainstorming personal experiences could take an unpredictable amount of time. I especially enjoyed this class because of the wonderful professor and the fantastic, diverse, group of peers. If possible, shop two sections to see how you feel about the group of people taking the class.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Small groups/individual meetings with professor
Some in-person one-on-one meetings.
We started off meeting twice a week as a whole class, but we also tried meeting in small groups and also individually with Professor Sharlin.
in-person office hours and small discussion groups

Professor Sharlin redid the whole schedule about halfway through the semesterto allow more flexibility in our class meeting times and to reduce our workload, overall reducing our stress. Some of our full-class meetings were thus replaced with small-group meetings of 1-3 people along with the professor.
